lines.content: //An enum class for the types of input
* A class ChatBox to simulate the chat features of the "Duke" by interacting
* with the user-inputs and responding accordingly.
//Use Java ArrayList collection to store all the instances of Task
* This is the method that enables the interactive feature for Luke. It keeps track
* of user-inputs and respond accordingly based on the different inputs (Marking, Unmarking,
//The important keywords to check against with the user-input
//The Strings representing the 3 types of Tasks
//An instance of Scanner to keep track of the user's input
"Please enter valid inputs, empty strings or blanks are not valid!\n" +
//To obtain the first word in the user-input, used to check for keyword "mark"
System.out.println("Here are the tasks in your to-do list:");
//Exception: Throw an error when user tries to delete from an empty list
"OOPS!!! There are no task left to be deleted!\n" +
//Exception: Throw an error when the second half after "delete" keyword is blank
"OOPS!!! The task number for deleting must be specified!\n" +
//Exception: Throw an error when the second half after "delete" keyword is greater than task_list
"OOPS!!! There is no such task number!\n" +
System.out.println("Noted. I have removed this task:");
System.out.println("Now you have " + task_list.size() + " tasks in the list.");
//Exception: Throw an error when the second half after "mark" keyword is blank
"OOPS!!! The task number for marking must be specified!\n" +
//Exception: Throw an error when the second half after "mark" keyword is greater than task_list
"OOPS!!! There is no such task number!\n" +
System.out.println("Good Job! I have marked this task as done:");
//Exception: Throw an error when the second half after "unmark" keyword is blank
"OOPS!!! The task number for un-marking must be specified!\n" +
//Exception: Throw an error when the second half after "unmark" keyword is greater than task_list
"OOPS!!! There is no such task number!\n" +
System.out.println("Alright! I have marked this task as not done yet:");
//Exception: Throw an error when the second half after "todo" keyword is blank
"OOPS!!! The description of a todo cannot be empty.\n" +
System.out.println("Got it. I have added this task:");
System.out.println("Now you have 1 task in the list.");
System.out.println("Now you have " + task_list.size() + " tasks in the list.");
//Exception: Throw an error when the second half after "deadline" keyword is blank
"OOPS!!! The description of a deadline cannot be empty.\n" +
System.out.println("Got it. I have added this task:");
System.out.println("Now you have 1 task in the list.");
System.out.println("Now you have " + task_list.size() + " tasks in the list.");
//Exception: Throw an error when the second half after "event" keyword is blank
"OOPS!!! The description of a event cannot be empty.\n" +
System.out.println("Got it. I have added this task:");
System.out.println("Now you have 1 task in the list.");
System.out.println("Now you have " + task_list.size() + " tasks in the list.");
//Exception: When the user-input does not specify within the 3 different tasks mentioned above
"OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I don't know what that means :-(\n" +
* The Deadline class extends from Task as it is a more specific/well-defined
* task, it is differentiated with the "deadline" keyword in user-input.
//String field to store details after /by keyword
* Constructor method for an instance of Deadline and it also utilises
* the constructor of it's parent class (Task)
* @param description String that contains the details about the task
* @param by String that contains the information of the deadline
* A string method to represent the Deadline task.
* @return a string representation of a task with a Deadline
* This method is a self-introduction for the Luke Bot.
System.out.println(("Hola Amigo! My name is\n" + logo));
System.out.println(("How may I assist you today?"));
* The Event class extends from Task as it is a more specific/well-defined
* task, it is differentiated with the "event" keyword in user-input.
//String field to store the details after /at keyword
* Constructor method for an instance of Event and it also utilises
* the constructor of it's parent class (Task)
* @param description String that contains the details about the task
* @param at String that contains the information of the specific time of event
* A string method to represent the Event task.
* @return a string representation of a task with a specific time-frame.
* This class is used to simulate the individual task entered by the
* user and encapsulates the task description as well as task status
//To encapsulate the information regarding the task
//To keep track of the status of the task (done/not done)
* This is a constructor for Task. It creates an instance of Task and sets
* the fields of the Task instance.
* @param description This is a String describing the task to be done.
* This method is used to check the status of the task (done/undone)
* and mark it with an X if it is done.
* @return a String representation of "X" for tasks that are done and
* an empty space " " for tasks that are undone.
return (isDone ? "X" : " "); // mark done task with X
* This method is used to mark the field isDone for each task as done (true).
* This method is used to mark the field isDone for each task as undone (false).
* This method provides a string representation of the task status and task
* @return a String representation of the formatted task.
* The Todo class extends from Task as it is a more specific/well-defined
* task, it is differentiated by having no deadline/due dates in user-input.
* Constructor method for an instance of Todo and it also utilises
* the constructor of it's parent class (Task)
* @param description String that contains the details about the task
* A string method to represent the Todo task.
* @return a string representation of a task without deadline/due dates.
